title: 110_s2471
content: The Act may be cited as the "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" and includes reforms to the USERRA complaint process. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 includes amendments to the notification of rights with respect to complaints and the expedition of attempts to investigate and resolve complaints under section 4322 of title 38, United States Code. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code to expedite the investigation and resolution of complaints submitted to the Secretary, requiring actions to be completed within 90 days. Additionally, referrals to the Attorney General or special counsel must be made within 15 days of receiving a request regarding a complaint. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code to expedite complaint investigations and resolutions. Referrals to the Attorney General or special counsel must be made within 15 days of receiving a request. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 amends procedures for notification of representation by the Attorney General or special counsel within 45 days of receiving a referral under paragraph (1). The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 amends procedures for notification by special counsel within 45 days of receiving a referral under paragraph (1). The special counsel must make a decision and notify the person within the specified timeframe. SEC. 3. EXPANSION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS FOR USERRA ENFORCEMENT. Expansion of reporting requirements for USERRA enforcement includes amending Section 4332 of title 38, United States Code to specify the number of cases reviewed by the Secretary of Defense through the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve of the Department of Defense during the fiscal year, as well as cases involving the same person seeking employment or reemployment. The reporting requirements for USERRA enforcement have been expanded to include specifying the number of cases reviewed by the Secretary of Defense through the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve of the Department of Defense during the fiscal year, including cases involving the same person seeking employment or reemployment, disability-related issues, and types of disabilities. The reporting requirements for USERRA enforcement have been expanded to include specifying the number of cases involving a person seeking employment or reemployment with a disability, and the types of disabilities. Additionally, the Comptroller General is required to submit quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel regarding cases where the Secretary did not meet certain requirements under USERRA. The Comptroller General must report quarterly to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel on cases where requirements under USERRA were not met. The report should include the number of cases with various issues such as missed referrals and non-compliance with requirements. The Comptroller General must report quarterly to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel on cases where USERRA requirements were not met. This includes cases with missed referrals and non-compliance with requirements. The Secretary shall coordinate with relevant parties to ensure uniform categorization of data in the reports. The Secretary will coordinate with relevant parties to ensure uniform categorization of data in reports required under section 4332, with electronic access to case files for specified officials. The amendments made by this section will apply to reports after the enactment of this Act.
